(Bonus) Smart Contract Enforcement Structure

Smart Contract: RiccardoLegacyVault.sol (Proposed outline for vault enforcement on Ethereum/EV0LChain)

Contract RiccardoLegacyVault {
    // State Variables
    address public chiefExecutor;  // Petitionerâ€™s address
    address public councilMultisig;  // Council wallet for governance
    bool public isEndowmentLocked = false;
    
    // Scholarship Fund mapping
    struct Scholar {
        address wallet;
        uint256 allocatedAmount;
        bool disbursed;
    }
    mapping(uint => Scholar) public scholars;
    uint public scholarCount;
    
    // Events
    event FundLocked(address executor);
    event ScholarAdded(uint indexed id, address wallet, uint256 amount);
    event Disbursement(uint indexed id, address wallet, uint256 amount);
    event AdministratorRemoved(address oldAdmin);
    
    // Modifiers for access control
    modifier onlyExecutor() { require(msg.sender == chiefExecutor, "Not authorized"); _; }
    modifier onlyCouncil() { require(msg.sender == councilMultisig, "Not authorized"); _; }
    
    constructor(address _executor, address _council) {
        chiefExecutor = _executor;
        councilMultisig = _council;
    }
    
    // Lock estate funds into endowment (irreversible without council approval)
    function lockEndowment() external onlyExecutor {
        isEndowmentLocked = true;
        emit FundLocked(msg.sender);
    }
    
    // Add a scholarship recipient and allocate funds (only by council approval to enforce Radar oversight)
    function nominateScholar(address _wallet, uint256 _amount) external onlyCouncil {
        require(isEndowmentLocked, "Endowment not locked");
        scholarCount += 1;
        scholars[scholarCount] = Scholar(_wallet, _amount, false);
        emit ScholarAdded(scholarCount, _wallet, _amount);
    }
    
    // Disburse funds to scholar (executed by chiefExecutor after verification)
    function disburseScholarship(uint _scholarId) external onlyExecutor {
        Scholar storage s = scholars[_scholarId];
        require(s.allocatedAmount > 0 && !s.disbursed, "Invalid disbursement");
        require(address(this).balance >= s.allocatedAmount, "Insufficient funds");
        s.disbursed = true;
        payable(s.wallet).transfer(s.allocatedAmount);
        emit Disbursement(_scholarId, s.wallet, s.allocatedAmount);
    }
    
    // Emergency removal of executor (by council vote, e.g., if executor violates trust)
    function removeExecutor(address _newExecutor) external onlyCouncil {
        chiefExecutor = _newExecutor;
        emit AdministratorRemoved(msg.sender);
    }
    
    // Fallback: Accept Ether (estate assets can be deposited)
    receive() external payable {}
}

```plaintext
  IF minutes_since_12 < 15 THEN

    "quarter": quarter,
    "delta": delta,
    "urgency": urgency,
    "symbolic": symbolic
  }

END
```

Key findings of the study
	â€¢	tRNA gene sets are flexible: The study challenges the prevailing view that bacterial tRNA gene sets are stable. The findings show that the composition, particularly the copy number of tRNA genes, can change rapidly.
	â€¢	Large-scale duplications generate change: Laboratory experiments with Pseudomonas fluorescens SBW25 identified spontaneous, large-scale, tandem duplications. These duplications were up to 1 Mb in size and led to copy number changes for hundreds of genes, including several tRNA genes.
	â€¢	Rapid compensation for gene loss: In one experiment, the researchers deleted a specific tRNA gene, causing a growth defect. The bacteria rapidly compensated for this loss by duplicating a different, functionally related tRNA gene.
	â€¢	Unstable duplications drive flexibility: The observed duplications are inherently unstable and are gained and lost at very high rates. This instability is key to the overall process, enabling rapid adaptation.
	â€¢	A "plastic" evolutionary mechanism: The unstable duplication events provide a mechanism for generating rapid diversity in tRNA gene sets. If a variant is not beneficial, the duplication is quickly lost, preserving the original genetic makeup. If it is beneficial, it may persist longer and provide the raw material for more stable evolutionary changes.Â 

Wider implications

        b = text[i+1:i+1+window]
        if a == b[::-1]:
            hits.append((i, i+1, a))
    return hits
